page.text: Description of the development (include all of the following that are known at the time of the application):
Location relative to major elements of the existing transportation system (e.g., the site is located
in the southwest quadrant of the intersection of Main Street/ First Street, 600 metres from the
Maple Street Rapid Transit Station); Existing land uses or permitted use provisions in the Official
Proposed land uses and relevant planning regulations to be used in the analysis;
Proposed development size (building size, number of residential units, etc.) and location on site;
Proposed number of parking spaces (not relevant for Draft Plans of Subdivision); and
Proposed access points and type of access (full turns, right-in/ right-out, turning restrictions,
Horizon years (include reference to phased development).
The CTS must include a key plan that shows the general location of the development in relation to
the surrounding area. The CTS must also provide a draft site plan or development concept of a
suitable scale that shows the general location of the development and the proposed access
locations. If the proposed development/ redevelopment is to be constructed in phases, a
description must be provided for each phase, identifying the proposed timing of implementation.
Existing roads and ramps in the study area, including jurisdiction, classification, number of lanes,
Existing intersections, indicating type of control, lane configurations, turning restrictions, and any
other relevant data (e.g., extraordinary lane widths, grades, etc.);
Existing access points to adjacent developments (both sides of all roads bordering the site);
Existing transit system, including stations and stops;
Existing on- and off-road bicycle facilities and pedestrian sidewalks and pathway networks;
Major trip generators/ attractors within the Study Area should be indicated.
The CTS report must include figures documenting the existing travel demands by mode. A photographic
inventory of the transportation network elements in the vicinity of the proposed access points would be
beneficial to staff in their review of the Consultant’s report.
Changes to the study area road network;
include figures documenting total future travel demands by mode for each horizon year.

text.b: Mitigation Measures and Site Design Characteristics

page.text: The CTS must identify all mitigation measures required to offset network impacts from the development. The
CTS must also identify key site design features required to implement the Official Plan and Transportation
Master Plan policies regarding site development.
The CTS must include all of the following, where they are required by the subject development:
Major network elements required to bring the screenlines to or below acceptable operating
guidelines, and comments regarding consistency of the requirements with the Transportation
Location and timing of proposed changes to existing traffic controls at intersections (e.g., new
Location and timing of new intersections, including proposed traffic control measures (e.g., traffic
Mitigation measures required to offset impacts on the surface and Rapid Transit networks;
New or modified elements of the bicycle and pedestrian networks;
Demonstration that Official Plan policies regarding transit-supportive developments have been
incorporated appropriately; and Proposed TDM features or programs to support the site

page.text: Trip Generation based on ITE Land-Use
City of Ottawa Strategic Screenline System
A residential development is proposed as part of a Zoning By-law Amendment and Site Plan
Application at 335 Roosevelt Avenue in Ottawa. The site is located at the north end of Roosevelt
Avenue on a site currently occupied by Fendor Glass & Aluminum Ltd., a light industrial land-use.
The trapezoidal site is bounded to the north by a multi-use pathway abutting the Transitway, an
apartment complex to the east, and a residential neighbourhood to the west and south. The site is
within 600m of two Transitway stations, Dominion and Westboro.
The intersections to be evaluated in this report were confirmed with the City prior to the preparation
of this report. The periods for analysis include the weekday AM and PM peak hours. The traffic
generated during the Saturday peak hour is lower than the weekday peak hours for a residential
development, and was not assessed. Analysis has been completed assuming 220 dwelling units
for a 2015 full build-out and the five year horizon of 2020.
A compound annual growth rate of 1% has been used to estimate future background traffic levels.
Trips generated by the proposed development have been estimated using peak hour rates identified in
Edition. Total future traffic volumes have been calculated by
adding the proposed site traffic to the projected background traffic volumes. All trips that will be
generated by Phase II development of the Westboro Station have been added to the background
traffic volumes, and included as part of the 2015 and 2020 background traffic projections.
Intersection capacity analysis was undertaken for the future background and total traffic conditions.
A screenline analysis has been completed in order to compare the forecasted demand and
available capacity of the major road network connecting the site to the area transportation network.
It was agreed with City staff that the forecasted traffic demand and future lane capacity at the CPR
Screenline should be analyzed for the year 2031, which is the horizon year of the City of Ottawa
The redevelopment of the site (335 Roosevelt Avenue) was included in the City of Ottawa’s
Richmond Road / Westboro Community Design Plan Transportation Impact Study (TIS). The study
concludes that transportation demand management (TDM) initiatives are the only feasible solution
to automobile congestion in Westboro village. As a result, the City has developed a
comprehensive strategy plan to remove barriers to non-auto uses in the village, and increase
transit modal splits to achieve the objectives stated in the Westboro TIS.
Provisions for non-auto travel modes were assessed, including access to local pedestrian, bicycle
and transit systems. The planned development is located within 600m of the Dominion and
Westboro Transitway stations which provide full access to the OC Transpo transit system. The site
features strong pedestrian linkages to the local sidewalk system, and features a central pedestrian
plaza that is linked to an existing multiuse pathway that parallels the Transitway from Roosevelt
Avenue to Churchill Avenue. The proposed on-site design was reviewed in terms of vehicle
access, on-site parking, and loading activities.
Community concerns and mitigation of potential community impacts were discussed at two open
houses and have been included in the report. Residents expressed concerns with cut through
traffic between Richmond Road and Churchill Avenue. A cul-de-sac will be introduced at the end
of Roosevelt Avenue to replace existing gates on the Fendor site, thus eliminating any possible
cut-through traffic. Other concerns regarding off-site traffic issues will be relayed to City Traffic
Based on the results of the foregoing analysis, the main conclusions and recommendations of this
• The signalized intersection of Richmond Road and Roosevelt Avenue operates with acceptable
v/c ratios during the AM and PM peak hours in the 2015 buildout year and the 2020 horizon.
Maximum traffic queues on Richmond Road are not expected to impact adjacent intersections.
• At the Richmond Road and Churchill Avenue intersection, the westbound through movement
on Richmond Road and the southbound through movement on Churchill Avenue are expected
to operate with a failing LOS during the 2015 and 2020 PM peak hour without the addition of
site traffic. Minor adjustments to traffic signal timing could offer marginal improvement, but
cannot provide an acceptable LOS during peak hours.
• The City of Ottawa is aware of the existing traffic congestion at the Richmond Road and
Churchill Avenue intersection and throughout the Richmond Road corridor. Opportunities to
add additional capacity are limited, and are not supported by the community at large. The City
has studied the issue and is implementing a number of demand management strategies within
the Westboro community to achieve a 40% Transit Modal Share (TMS).
• The unsignalized intersection of Churchill Avenue and Wilmont Avenue operates with
acceptable LOS in the 2015 buildout and the 2020 horizon. Minimal delays are expected for
left turning traffic on Churchill Avenue.
• The unsignalized intersection of Churchill Avenue and Scott Street operates with acceptable
LOS in the 2015 buildout and the 2020 horizon. Traffic control signals are not warranted based
• The background traffic condition is predicated on background traffic volumes growing annually
at a rate of 1%. Historic traffic count data indicates that traffic volumes are generally
decreasing within the study area. Moreover, the modal split targets in the Transportation
Master Plan and in the Richmond Road/Westboro TIS are higher than those assumed for the
planned development. Therefore, we consider the results of the analysis of projected
background traffic conditions to be conservative.
• It is expected that the implementation of the Rapid Transit Network identified in the TMP, most
notably the introduction of Light Rail Transit to downtown Ottawa, will ensure that the TMS
targets are achieved by 2031. The analysis at the CPR Screenline assumes a Transit Modal
Split (TMS) of 51% in the AM peak hour and 52% in the PM peak hour.
• The proposed development conforms to the City’s TDM initiatives by creating a development that
fosters the use of healthy and sustainable non-auto modes of transportation. The location of the
development to two major Transitway stations, numerous on-site pedestrian connections to
existing sidewalks and multi-use pathways on/near the site, creation of a large central pedestrian
plaza are a few features that support the City’s TDM initiatives.
• Accesses will be designed in compliance with Private Approach By-Law through the site plan
• Parking infiltration on area roadways is not anticipated.
• No significant changes in traffic operations are expected at the study area intersections with
the addition of site traffic. The increases in v/c ratios, queue length, and delay are expected to
• No further mitigation measures, other than TDM, are required to accommodate the addition of
We recommend that the City approve the proposed development due to the minor impact on the
surrounding transportation network, the close integration of pedestrian links within and through the
site, and other development features that support using non-auto modes of travel.
A residential development is proposed as part of a Zoning By-law Amendment and future Site Plan
Application at 335 Roosevelt Avenue in Ottawa. The impact of a proposed 220 dwelling unit
development on the neighbouring transportation network has been analysed. The final unit count
will be determined during the approval of the site plan. The trapezoidal site is bounded by the
dead-end of Roosevelt Avenue to the west, the Transitway to the north, a residential tower to the
east, and Wilmont Avenue to the south. Fendor Glass & Aluminum Ltd., which currently occupies
much of the proposed site, has gated accesses at Roosevelt Avenue and at Wilmont Avenue. In
addition to providing security for the light industrial site, these gates restrict local traffic from
shortcutting between Richmond Road and Churchill Avenue. A key plan is included as Figure 1.
The proposed development consists of two (2) condominium towers yielding approximately 220
units. Vehicular accesses are proposed at Roosevelt Avenue and Wilmont Avenue. A concept
site plan is included as Figure 2.
The proposed development evaluated for the purposes of this study consists of the following:
• 2 towers with an approximate total of 220 condominium units;
• underground and above ground parking space.
The condominium buildings will share an underground parking garage with two-way ramp
accesses at Roosevelt Avenue and at Wilmont Avenue. The preliminary ground floor site plan is
The expected completion date for the entire development is 2015.
The types of analysis undertaken to assess the transportation impacts of the revised development
are consistent with the requirements of the Ottawa Transportation Impact Assessment (TIA)
Intersection capacity analysis has been completed using the software package Synchro 6.0. This
software uses methodology from the Highway Capacity Manual 2000 (HCM), published by the
Transportation Research Board, to evaluate signalized and unsignalized intersections.
Intersection operating conditions are commonly described in terms of a Level of Service (LOS).
LOS is a qualitative measurement of speed, freedom to manoeuvre, interruptions, comfort and
convenience. Letters are assigned to six levels, with LOS ‘A’ representing optimal operating
conditions and LOS ‘F’ representing failing operating conditions.
The City of Ottawa has adopted criteria that directly relate the LOS of a signalized intersection to a
volume to capacity (v/c) ratio. Vehicle capacity is defined as the maximum number of vehicles that
can pass a given point during a specified period under prevailing traffic conditions. The City’s
The LOS for an unsignalized intersection is based on average control delay and is defined for
individual movements. Control delay includes initial deceleration, queue move-up time, stopped
time and final acceleration. The HCM presents the following criteria relating the LOS for individual
In this study, movements at signalized and unsignalized intersections have been evaluated in
terms of the LOS as defined in the foregoing tables. Mitigation measures in the form of additional
lane capacity and/or signal adjustments have been identified for movements with a LOS E or F.
Signalization warrants were completed for the unsignalized intersection of Churchill Avenue and
Scott Street using the 8 hour count counted by Novatech on January 18, 2011.
This Combined Community Transportation Study (CTS) / TIS has been prepared to provide an
assessment of the development proposal. The methodologies used to analyze the transportation
impacts of the proposed development are described as follows:
• An operational evaluation of the site access and study area intersections under the
background and total traffic conditions for the weekday AM and PM peak hours;
• A screenline analysis in order to compare the forecasted demand and available capacity of
the major road network connecting the site to the area transportation network;
• An assessment of provisions for non-auto travel modes, including integration with local
transit service, and connections with the local pedestrian and bicycle networks;
• A review of the proposed on-site design in terms of access, parking facilities, and
• An evaluation of conformance with Transportation Demand Management (TDM) principles.
The study area for this report was confirmed with City staff, and includes the proposed accesses
on Roosevelt Avenue and Wilmont Avenue as well as the following intersections:
The selected time periods for analysis are the weekday AM and PM peak hours. The weekday AM
and PM peak hours are considered to represent the ‘worst-case’ combination of site-generated
traffic and adjacent street traffic. Existing traffic conditions within the study area have been
examined, along with background and total traffic conditions at the build-out year (2015) and a five-
Results of the analysis were compared with the results of the City’s Richmond Road / Westboro
Community Design Plan Transportation Impact Study (TIS) for consistency. The results of the
transportation assessment for the Churchill Avenue corridor completed by Novatech as part of the
Churchill Avenue Reconstruction (Scott Street to Carling Avenue) were also used as part of the
validation process for this study. It is worthwhile noting that the study included additional trips
generated by the redevelopment of the proposed site (335 Roosevelt Avenue).
Churchill Avenue is a two-lane urban arterial roadway with a north-south alignment between Scott
Street and Richmond Road with a 20m protected ROW. On-street parking is generally permitted
along both sides of the roadway between Scott Street and Tillbury Avenue. The City of Ottawa has
designated Churchill Avenue as a truck route; however trucks are prohibited on Churchill Avenue
south of Richmond Road between 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. On-street parking is not permitted
along the northbound and southbound approaches of the Churchill Avenue / Richmond Road
intersection. The north end of the roadway has been designated as an arterial main street, and is
a transportation hub for the neighbourhood with access to the Transitway. The posted speed is 50
Richmond Road is a two-lane urban arterial main street with an east-west alignment, with a ROW
width of 20 meters. It is a designated truck route, and on-street parking is permitted on both sides
of the roadway. Small bulbouts have been introduced at Churchill Avenue to reduce pedestrian
crossing distances at the intersection. On-street parking is prohibited on the westbound approach
to Roosevelt Avenue. Within the limits of the study area, the posted speed on Richmond Road is
Roosevelt Avenue is a north/south two-lane local road with curbs and concrete sidewalk on the
east side and, north of Richmond Road, the west side of the street is uncurbed. Parking is
permitted from approximately 70m north of the Richmond Road intersection. Roosevelt Avenue
terminates at a dead-end at the entrance to the Fendor site.
Wilmont Avenue is two lane rural local road whose western end meets Winston Avenue and the gated
access to the Fendor site and eastern end crosses Churchill Avenue at a stop controlled tee intersection.
Winston Street is a two lane rural local road that has been dead-ended before meeting Richmond
Road. The west access to the Fendor site is provided through a gate at the cul-de-sac.
The Richmond Road / Roosevelt Avenue intersection operates under coordinated actuated traffic
signal control with single lane approaches. No designated turn lanes are provided. Parking is
prohibited on Richmond Road at the westbound approach to the intersection. Pedestrian
crosswalks are provided on all arms.
The Richmond Road / Churchill Avenue intersection operates under coordinated actuated traffic
signal control with designated eastbound and westbound left turn lanes. The northbound and
southbound approaches are delineated as single lanes; however, it is noted from recent on-site
observations that there is sufficient pavement width on both approaches to accommodate two
traffic streams at the stop bar. When left turning traffic is present at these approaches, the through
traffic and right turning traffic use the remaining pavement to slip past left turning traffic. For the
purposes of the analysis, we have assumed that the northbound and southbound approaches
operate as through right with unpainted left turn lanes with a nominal length of 30m. Pedestrian
crosswalks are provided on all arms.
The tee intersection of Wilmont Avenue and Churchill Avenue operates with stop control on
Wilmont Avenue with free-flow conditions maintained on Churchill Avenue. A pedestrian crosswalk
is provided across Wilmont Avenue on the west side of Churchill Avenue.
The intersection of Churchill Avenue and Scott Street operates under all-way stop control with
single lane approaches. Pedestrian crosswalks are provided on all arms. An MTO signalization
warrant for this intersection was completed using the 8 hour traffic count conducted by Novatech
on January 18, 2011 (Appendix F). The results of the MTO signalization warrant calculation
indicate that signals are not warranted under existing traffic conditions, nor are they likely to be
warranted with the addition of site traffic before the 2020 horizon year. This is consistent with the
findings in the transportation assessment for the preliminary design of the Churchill Avenue
Reconstruction, and the Richmond Road / Westboro CDP TIS. The CDP TIS found that signals
may be justified in the 2021 horizon year based on potential land use development as identified in
A concrete sidewalk on the east side of Roosevelt Avenue leads to a shared multi-use pathway
that runs parallel to the south side of the Transitway between Roosevelt Avenue and Churchill
Avenue. A concrete sidewalk is provided on the north side of Wilmont Avenue, and an asphalt
sidewalk is provided on the west side of Winston Avenue.
Sidewalks are provided along both sides of Richmond Road and Churchill Avenue within the study
area. The sidewalks along Richmond Road are constructed using red unit pavers. The sidewalk
depressions at the Richmond Road and Churchill Avenue intersection have been constructed
using a grey unit paver to emphasise pedestrian crossing activity.
Depressed curbs are provided at all crosswalks within the study area.
The City of Ottawa’s Primary Urban Cycling network from the 2008 Transportation Master Plan
(TMP) designates Richmond Road, Scott Street and Roosevelt Avenue (north of Byron Road) as
on-road cycling routes. Designated cycling lanes are not provided along either street.
Richmond Road, Scott Street, and Roosevelt Avenue (north of Byron Avenue) are designated as a
Spine or City-wide Cycling Route in the City of Ottawa’s Ottawa Cycling Plan (OCP). The OCP
identifies Richmond Road (Golden Avenue to Tweedsmuir Avenue) as having an existing signed
shared cycling route, Roosevelt Avenue as having a proposed signed shared cycling lane, and
Scott Street has having a proposed bicycle lane.
A copy of the 2009 OC Transpo system map for the study area is included in Appendix A. This
report describes all existing transit facilities within a five minute walk of the subject site, which
equates to a distance of 400 metres. OC Transpo guidelines recommend that all development in
the vicinity of a bus route should have at least one bus stop within a walking distance of 400
The Dominion Transitway Station is located at walking distance of 220m from the site, while the
Westboro is located 450m from the site. Both provide access to many regular and express routes
The local routes that serve the community, OC Transpo Routes #2 and #18 (regular all-day) and
Routes #150 and #187 during peak hours, can be accessed at these OC Transpo stops:
• #7379 – east side of Churchill Avenue, north of Wilmont Avenue (200m walking distance);
• #7380 – west side of Churchill Avenue, north of Wilmont Avenue (180m walking distance);
• #7406 – north side of Richmond road, east of Roosevelt Avenue (290m walking distance);
• #7436 – south side of Richmond road, east of Roosevelt Avenue (315m walking distance).
Bus Stops #7378 and #5838 were eliminated during the first phase of the reconstruction of
Churchill Avenue. Route details are provided in Appendix A. Figure 1 shows the location of the
nearest bus stop locations to the proposed development.
Novatech Engineering completed 8 hour traffic counts at all the study area intersections on
January 18, 2011. Peak hour summary sheets are included in Appendix B for the following
Construction of Phase II of the Westboro Station is nearing completion, and will be ready for
occupancy prior to the planned opening of the proposed development 2015. We have added the
trips generated by this development in our background traffic.
Historical collision data from the last three years was obtained from the City’s Public Works and
Service Department for all study area intersections. Copies of the collision summary reports are
The collision data has been evaluated to determine if there are any identifiable collision patterns. The
Ottawa TIA Guidelines define a collision pattern as more than one collision involving similar directions
and impact types. Further analysis may be warranted for intersections with a pattern of six or more
collisions for any one movement or a total of 33 or more collisions, over a three-year period.
A total of 27 accidents were reported from January 1, 2007 to January 1, 2010 at the four
intersections in the study area. No fatalities were reported. The following table summarizes the
number of collisions reported at each intersection:
Four of the seven accidents at the intersection of Richmond Road and Roosevelt involved a single
motor vehicle hitting a pedestrian, a utility pole, or a stopped vehicle. There is no pattern to the
Eight of the seventeen accidents were single vehicle accidents involving pedestrians, cyclists, or
parked vehicles. Three accidents involved turning vehicles in wet weather, and one in clear
weather. Of the five remaining accidents, two were sideswipes, two were angle collisions, and one
was a rear end collision. No pattern was identified in the collisions.
The only accident reported at this intersection during the last three years was a single vehicle
collision which occurred on a clear morning.
Both reported accidents involved southbound vehicles colliding with eastbound cyclists.
These intersections do not meet the City’s criteria for further analysis with respect to collision
The City of Ottawa has completed the reconstruction of Churchill Avenue from Scott Street to
Byron Avenue. The completion of the reconstruction of Churchill Avenue (Byron Avenue to Carling
Avenue) is subject to funding approval by City Council.
The City of Ottawa 2008 Transportation Master Plan (TMP) identifies a proposed rapid transit
network that includes the Downtown Ottawa Transit Tunnel (DOTT), a 3 kilometre tunnel with
5 underground or partially underground stations to serve the downtown area. The construction of
the tunnel is expected to have a significant impact on traffic volumes in the downtown area.
Also, the TMP shows the implementation of the following initiatives in the area:
• cycling lanes and paved shoulders on Richmond Road between Moodie Drive & Churchill
• widening Richmond Road to four lanes (Carling Avenue to Golden Avenue) (2023 -2025);
• cycling lanes on Scott Street between Churchill Avenue & Lebreton Flats (2023-2025).
In addition to the works indentified in the TMP, the Richmond Road / Westboro Transportation
Management Implementation Plan (TMIP) recommends additional measures required to achieve a
40% modal split within the community. The report was approved by City Council on February 23,
2011. The recommendations of the TMIP are to be implemented on a phased basis in the near
term (2011-2015), interim term (2016-2020), and long term (2021-2025). The recommendations of
the TMIP can be summarized as follows:
• A pedestrian count-down signal is recommended to be immediately installed at Roosevelt
• A signed cycling route should be installed along Richmond Road from Golden Avenue to
Roosevelt Avenue and along Roosevelt Avenue from Richmond Road to the Scott Street
• One eastbound and one westbound cycling lane should be included along Scott Street
• One eastbound queue jump lane is recommended along Richmond Road at Churchill
Avenue, if future traffic levels warrant additional transit priority measures (interim term);
• Possible reductions of minimum parking requirements for developments within 600m of
Transitway stations and the possible imposition of maximum parking restrictions through re-
Possible regulations to support the provision of separating the rental cost of parking spaces
(unbundled parking) from dwelling rental and/or purchase agreements (near term).
The Transportation, Utilities and Public Works Department provided the following weekday traffic
• Richmond Road and Roosevelt Avenue (City 2005, City 2006, City 2009, Novatech 2011);
• Richmond Road and Churchill Avenue (City 2008, Novatech 2011);
• Churchill Avenue and Scott Street (City 2005, City 2008, Novatech 2011).
Count summaries are included in Appendix B. The historical two way approach volumes are
summarized in Table 2 during AM and PM peak hours.
The above table indicates that in recent years traffic volumes observed along Churchill Avenue,
Roosevelt Avenue and Scott Street show decreases, while Richmond Road shows a slightly
increasing trend. Municipal and private construction contracts in the area may have disrupted
traffic patterns. The reason for these variations is unclear; therefore background growth rates will
be generated using historic traffic data included in the City’s Transportation Master Plan (TMP)
Over a 26-year period between 2005 and 2031, the 2008 TMP projects an increase in automobile
travel demand of 4% at the CPR screenline. This equates to an annual growth rate of
approximately 0.2%. For the purposes of this study, a compound annual growth rate of 1.0% has
been conservatively assumed for all streets within the study area. This is consistent with the
background traffic growth rate used in the Richmond Road / Westboro Community Design Plan
Background traffic volumes for the 2015 and 2020 analysis years were estimated by applying the
1% growth rate to the existing traffic volumes which were obtained by adding the traffic generated
by Phase II of the West End Station development to the January 2011 traffic counts. The 2015
and 2020 background traffic projections are shown in Figures 4 and 5 respectively.
A review of heavy vehicle traffic was undertaken since Richmond Road, Churchill Avenue and
Scott Street are designated as truck routes under the City’s Transportation Master Plan within the
study area. Heavy vehicles are vehicles having one rear axle with four or more wheels, or having
two or more rear axles. These vehicles include O.C. Transpo, school and inter-city buses.
The percentage of heavy vehicle traffic was obtained by dividing the 8 hour total heavy volumes by
the 8 hour total traffic volumes along the street. The percentages of heavy vehicles, volumes of
pedestrian and bicycle traffic used in the Synchro analysis were derived from historic City of
Ottawa traffic counts to compensate for the effect of cold weather observed during the January 18
traffic counts. The percentage of Heavy Vehicles, and the volumes of pedestrian and bicycle traffic
on Churchill Avenue at the Wilmont Avenue were taken to be equal to those occurring on north
approach of the Churchill Avenue / Scott Street intersection. The percentages of Heavy Vehicles
used in the simulation varied by direction and approach, and are summarized in the following table:

text.b: Table 3: Percentage Heavy Vehicles, by approach

page.text: Westboro Station Phase II is currently under construction at the corner of Richmond Road and
Golden Avenue. For the purposes of this study, the turning traffic generated by the development at
the Richmond Road and Roosevelt Avenue intersection has been added to the background traffic
data (Figure 3). A copy of the trip generation data for Phase II of Westboro Station is included in
Site-generated traffic volumes for the proposed condominium units have been estimated based on
rates identified in the Trip Generation Manual (Institute of Transportation Engineers, 8th Edition).
The City’s Richmond Road/Westboro TIS uses a 20% Transit Modal Split (TMS) to analyse the
potential traffic generated by the redevelopment of the 335 Roosevelt Avenue property, and
concludes with a recommendation that a 40% TMS should become the City’s new target in the
Richmond Road corridor. Figure 2.11 of the City of Ottawa’s 2008 Transportation Master Plan
(TMP) reports that the Transit Modal Split (TMS) was 23% in 2005 for areas within the Greenbelt
Cordon. Given the proximity of the subject site to the Transitway, we feel that a 23% modal split to
transit modes is conservative and justified for this development. We have applied this rate to the
trips generated by the development. The results have been summarized as follows:

i.b: Table 4:-Trip Generation based on ITE Land Use

page.text: 1. ITE trip generation rates have been adjusted using a non-auto modal share factor of 0.77.
Weekday a.m. and p.m. peak hour site-generated traffic volumes are shown in Figure 6. The
traffic generated during the Saturday peak hour is lower than the weekday peak hours, and was
not assessed. All trips generated are assumed to be primary trips. These volumes are consistent
with the trip generation included in the Transportation Impact Study completed as part of the
Richmond Road / Westboro Community Design Plan. In the report, Sector 7 of the Richmond
Road / Westboro TIS included an additional 54 and 65 trips during the AM and PM peak hours to
be generated by redevelopment of 335 Roosevelt Avenue.
For the purposes of this preliminary traffic analysis, the study area intersections include Richmond
Road and Roosevelt Avenue, Richmond Road and Churchill Avenue, and Churchill Avenue and
Scott Street. Site-generated traffic was distributed based on the peak hour traffic patterns within
the study area. Trip distribution is assumed to be as follows:
• 5% - to/from the north via Churchill Avenue;
• 33% - to/from the east via Churchill Avenue;
• 17% - to/from the east via Richmond Road;
• 25% - to/from the west via Richmond Road;
• 20% - to/from the south via Churchill Avenue.
For the purposes of this analysis, it is assumed that all site traffic using the Winston Avenue
access will travel to and from Churchill Avenue using Wilmont Avenue. All trips to and from the
north and south via Churchill have been assigned to the Wilmont Avenue access; all trips to and
from the west have been assigned to Roosevelt Avenue. Trips to and from the east have been
assigned equally to the site accesses on Wilmont Avenue and Roosevelt Avenue. The resultant
traffic volumes on Roosevelt Avenue are below those forecasted in the Richmond Road / Westboro
Total traffic volumes for 2015 and 2020 have been calculated by adding the estimated site-
generated traffic with the background traffic projections. The 2015 and 2020 total traffic volumes
Intersection capacity analysis has been completed using the Synchro 6.0 software package.
Operating conditions at signalized intersections have been evaluated in terms of the volume to
capacity (v/c) ratio and the corresponding Level of Service (LOS) based on City of Ottawa criteria.
Operating conditions at unsignalized intersections have been evaluated in terms of delay and LOS
based on Highway Capacity Manual 2000 (HCM) criteria. Mitigation measures in the form of
additional lane capacity, intersection control modifications, and/or traffic signal adjustments have
been identified for movements with a LOS E or F.
Intersection capacity analysis has been completed for the projected 2015 background traffic
conditions. The results of the analysis are summarized in the following table for the weekday AM
and PM peak hours. Detailed reports are included in Appendix E1.
All approaches to the Richmond Road and Roosevelt intersection operate at a v/c ratio of 0.58 or
less (LOS A) during the AM and PM peak hours. Queue lengths on Roosevelt are expected to be
less than 15m during the AM and PM peak hours. The maximum eastbound queue length on
Richmond Road is expected to be 85m during the AM peak, and 40m during the PM peak hour.
The westbound queue length is expected to be less than 45m during the AM peak, and 105m in
All movements at the Richmond Road and Churchill Avenue intersection operate at a v/c of 0.74 or
better during both the AM and PM peak hours, except for the westbound through and southbound
through during the PM peak hour. During the PM peak, the westbound and southbound movements
operate with v/c ratios in excess of 0.96. Maximum queue lengths of 160m and 180m for the
westbound and southbound through movements respectively are expected. Queue lengths on these
approaches exceed the available storage capacity and may block upstream intersections. The
northbound queue length is expected to be approximately 15m which exceeds the storage provided.
The delay to traffic turning left from Wilmont Avenue onto Churchill Avenue is expected to be less than
16 seconds which corresponds to a Level of Service ‘C’. No significant delays are expected for traffic
turning left from Churchill Avenue onto Wilmont Avenue. The queue length for the northbound left-turn
movement can be approximated based on the maximum number of left-turning vehicles that are likely
to arrive during a two minute interval. This is calculated according to the following formula:
N = design volume of turning vehicles (veh/hr)
L = length of vehicles (m), assume 7m length
Based on the above formula, the maximum queue length is expected to be less than a car length
during the AM and PM peak hours and is considered negligible.

Intersection capacity analysis has been completed for the projected 2020 background traffic
conditions. The results of the analysis are summarized in the following table for the weekday AM
and PM peak hours. Detailed reports are included in Appendix E1.
All approaches to the Richmond Road and Roosevelt intersection operate at a v/c ratio of 0.61
(LOS B) in both the AM and PM peak hours. Queue lengths on Roosevelt are expected to be less
than 20m during the AM and PM peak hours. The maximum eastbound queue length on
Richmond Road is expected to be 100m during the AM peak hour, and 40m during the PM peak
hour. The maximum westbound queue length is expected to be less than 50m during the AM peak
hour, and 120m in the PM peak hour.
All approaches to the Richmond Road and Churchill Avenue intersection operate at a v/c of 0.78 or
better during both the AM and PM peak hours, except for the westbound through and southbound
through during the PM peak. Maximum queue lengths on each approach are expected to increase
by an average of 10m over the 2015 background traffic conditions. The northbound queue length
is expected to be less than 17m which exceeds the storage provided. During the PM peak, the
westbound and southbound movements operate at v/c ratios of 1.00 or greater; queue lengths on
these approaches exceed the storage provided and may block upstream intersections.
The delay to traffic turning left from Wilmont Avenue onto Churchill Avenue is expected to be
approximately 16 seconds or less which corresponds to a Level of Service ‘C’. No significant
delays or queues are expected for traffic turning left from Churchill Avenue onto Wilmont Avenue.

text.i: Churchill Avenue / Scott Street (4-way stop control)

page.text: Delays are expected to be approximately 12 seconds or less which corresponds to a Level of
Service ‘B’. Queue lengths for the predominant northbound right and westbound left-turn
movements are expected to be 60m or less.
From our analysis of background traffic, only the intersection of Richmond Road and Churchill
Avenue requires mitigation in the PM peak hour. Opportunities to add capacity to the intersection
by providing new traffic lanes and/or new auxiliary lanes are limited by the narrow right-of-ways,
and the designation of Richmond Road and the northern section of Churchill Avenue as arterial
Operational analysis was limited to optimising green times within the existing cycle length and
offset since traffic signals within the study area operate in a coordinated manner with other signals
in the area. A 10m reduction of the southbound through and right queues on Churchill Avenue
could be achieved by reallocating 4 seconds of green time from the eastbound left turn on
Richmond Road to the north/south through movements on Churchill Avenue. The largest change
in v/c ratio occurs for the southbound through movement on Churchill Avenue in the 2020 PM peak
hour; the v/c falls from 1.17 to 1.04. System-wide modeling of the traffic network is beyond the
scope of this report. Detailed reports are included in Appendix E3.
Based on the foregoing and as outlined in the Richmond Road / Westboro TIS, the only feasible
solutions to traffic congestion in the Westboro community is to shift auto trips away onto other
modes of transportation, and/or to provide capacity elsewhere in the transportation network making
Richmond Road and Churchill Avenue less attractive to commuter traffic. Section 3.1 discusses a
number of City infrastructure improvements to be planned in the greater Westboro area, including
the Westboro TMIP initiatives. Section 5.0 has a discussion of broad transportation needs and
objectives for the adjacent CPR screenline.

From our analysis of total traffic, only the intersection of Richmond Road and Churchill Avenue
requires mitigation in the PM peak hour (Detailed reports are included in Appendix E3).
Our analysis shows that changes resulting from site traffic have a minimal impact on the
performance of the transportation network in the study area. As previously discussed in Section
4.3, the key to mitigating impact of the planned development is to support City Transportation
Demand Management initiatives in the area to decrease the magnitude of background peak hour
traffic along Richmond Road and Churchill Avenue. This is discussed further in Section 6.0 and
In accordance with the requirements of the City of Ottawa Transportation Impact Assessment
guidelines, a screenline analysis has been completed in order to compare the forecasted demand
and available capacity of the major road network connecting the site to the area transportation
network. It was agreed with City staff that the forecasted traffic demand and future lane capacity at
the CPR Screenline should be analyzed for the year 2031, which is the horizon year of the City of
Relative to the subject site, the CPR screenline is the closest screenline in the City of Ottawa’s
Strategic Screenline System. The CPR screenline (#27-29) follows the CPR railway corridor from
the Ottawa River Parkway to Colonel By Drive, and is shown in Appendix G. The projected
transportation demand, transit modal shares, and lane capacities at the CPR screenline in 2031
have been derived from the City of Ottawa’s TRANS model, and the Road Infrastructure Needs
The TRANS model identifies a target Transit Modal Split (TMS) of 51% in the AM peak hour
(observed at 37% in 2005), and a TMS of 52% in the PM peak hour (observed at 32% in 2005). It
is expected that these targets can be achieved through the implementation of light rail transit (LRT)
within the downtown area (including the aforementioned DOTT), and the development of Carling
Avenue as a supplementary LRT corridor between Lincoln Fields Station and the Carling O-Train
Station, as outlined in the TMP Rapid Transit Network. The downtown transit priority measures
proposed in the TMP will also improve the competitiveness of transit compared to the car, by
reducing travel times along major bus routes and improving service reliability. It is expected that
the improved competitiveness of transit will result in greater levels of transit utilization. The TMP
Rapid Transit Network is included in this report as Appendix H.
If the 2008 TMP forecast that these TMSs will be achieved by the horizon year 2031 is assumed to
be accurate, the screenline analysis may be summarized as follows:
3. Auto occupancy rate taken from Road Infrastructure Needs Study (Delcan)
4. Commercial vehicle factor taken from Road Infrastructure Needs Study (Delcan), assumes 5% HGVs & 6% LGVs
The screenline analysis indicates that in 2031, a deficiency of 490 pcu is anticipated at the CPR
screenline during the AM peak hour. No deficiency is anticipated during the PM peak hour. Based
on the foregoing calculations, it is anticipated that the major road network in the vicinity of the
screenline will operate with LOS E (v/c = 0.93) and LOS D (v/c = 0.89) during the AM and PM peak
hours respectively. If no additional lane capacity is provided, traffic congestion is expected to
occur during the AM peak hour by the horizon year 2031. It is expected that the development of
Carling Avenue as a supplementary LRT corridor will effectively eliminate the possibility of
providing additional lane capacity along Carling Avenue to address the AM peak hour deficiency.
However, the TMP outlines a number of future road projects that are intended to develop both new
and existing east-west road corridors beyond the CPR Screenline. Relevant examples include:
• the widening of Hunt Club Road from 4 lanes to 6 lanes between Riverside Drive and
• the extension of Hunt Club Road east to Highway 417;
• the construction of the Strandherd-Earl Armstrong Bridge across the Rideau River;
• the construction of a new bridge across the Rideau River between Hunt Club Road and the
• the widening of Riverside Drive from 2 lanes to 6 lanes (in two phases), from Hunt Club
Most of the road projects listed above are designed to address capacity deficiencies at the Rideau
River and Manotick screenlines. However, it is possible that these improvements will also have a
greater residual effect on the CPR screenline than had been previously anticipated, potentially
reducing or eliminating the projected AM peak hour deficiency at the CPR screenline.
The possibility of achieving a 2031 AM peak hour TMS that exceeds the TMP target of 51%
identified should also be considered. If a TMS of 53% can be achieved during the AM peak hour
by 2031, no capacity deficiency is expected at the screenline.
If implemented, the recommendations of the Richmond Road / Westboro Transportation
Management Implementation Plan (TMIP) will help shift traffic demand from automobiles to transit,
and achieve the 40% modal split target. A targeted 8% reduction of automobile demand from the
Richmond Road/Westboro community will help to increase the TMS (at the screenline) beyond the
51% target, thereby eliminating the need to provide additional lane capacity at the screenline
Mitigating factors notwithstanding, it is concluded that at least some congestion will be observed on
the major road network close to the subject site during the AM peak hour in 2031.
Given the relatively small scale of the proposed development and that the land use is consistent
with the City’s official plan, we assume that traffic impacts of the development site would have
included within the growth factors used in the City wide screenline analysis. Therefore, the impact
of the proposed development on the overall CPR screenline will be negligible.
As part of the development of the site plan, pedestrian links will be provided though the site.
Connections will be made to the sidewalk on Roosevelt, and the pedestrian facilities at the Winston
Avenue / Wilmont Avenue intersection. Connections to the multi-use pathway abutting the
Transitway will also be provided. Bicycle parking will be provided on-site in accordance with the
requirements of the Zoning By-law. Additional bicycle parking could be provided along the multi-use
pathway and the pedestrian links from the site on City property.
On-site pedestrian connections will allow easy access to OC Transpo bus stops on Churchill
Avenue and Richmond Road and to the Dominion and Westboro Transitway stations via the
existing multi-use pathways that run adjacent to the site and parallel to the Transitway
This section of the report provides a review of the on-site design in terms of vehicle access, on-site
Two access points will be provided to the development. A two-way access will be provided on
Roosevelt Avenue, and the second two-way access will be provided on Wilmont Avenue. Two
ramps to/from the underground will be provided allowing residents to choose the appropriate
access/egress point for their trip. Resident and visitor parking for the site will be provided in the
underground parking garage shared by both buildings. There will be a provision for some
additional visitor parking at grade. There will be no direct surface link from Wilmont Avenue or
The location of the access points will be developed during the finalisation of the site plan. Each
access will meet the requirements of the Private Approach By-law.
The site is located in Area B of Schedule 1 to the Zoning By-law and within 600 meters of a rapid
transit station. Minimum parking space rates for the proposed development are outlined as
• Residential (visitors) – 0.2 per dwelling unit, from 12 units to a maximum of 300 units
The maximum parking space rate for the proposed development is outlined as follows:
• Residential (occupants) – 1.75 per dwelling unit, resident and visitor combined
Based on the approximate total of 220 units for this development, the Zoning By-Law indentifies a
minimum requirement to provide at least 110 parking spaces for residents, and 42 spaces for
visitors. The maximum permissible number of parking spaces that can be provided on-site is 385.
The current site plan concept provides 12 surface spaces for visitors and a further 208
underground parking stalls for residents and visitors. The location, type, and number of parking
spaces will be finalised at the site plan approval stage.
The Zoning By-law requires a minimum of 0.50 bicycle parking spaces per dwelling unit for the
proposed residential land use. Applying these rates to the proposed development identifies a
minimum requirement to provide 110 bicycle parking spaces. On-site bicycle parking will be
provided in accordance with the minimum requirements of the Zoning By-law.
No specific details relating to the location, frequency and duration of loading activities and garbage
removal are available at this time. This will be addressed at the site plan approval stage.
The site is bounded by an apartment building to the east, single family homes to the south and
west, and by the Transitway to the north. Roosevelt Avenue and Wilmont Avenue are local roads
with low traffic volumes. The sites’ proximity to two Transitway stations and recreational pathway
systems will help minimize the impact of site-generated trips on local residents.
On-site underground parking for residents and on-site visitor parking will be provided in
accordance with the requirements of the Zoning By-law. Parking infiltration onto area roadways is
Open houses were held on August 12 and November 17, 2010 to introduce the proposed
development to the community, to gauge support, and to understand issues that are of concern to
the residents of the neighbourhood. The following issues were identified at the first open house by
• Access and traffic issues with the Starbucks at Roosevelt Avenue and Richmond Road.
A range of measures to address these existing traffic concerns was presented for discussion at the
second open house held in November. It is important to note that the proposed development does
not negatively impact these existing traffic issues, and that the responsibility to resolve these
The current site concept establishes a cul-de-sac at the end of Roosevelt Avenue that would
eliminate cut-through traffic on Roosevelt Avenue. Speed bumps could be implemented on
Roosevelt to discourage speeding, signage announcing the dead-end on Roosevelt could be
added to Richmond Road and Roosevelt Avenue to reduce u-turns, and minor modifications could
be made to curbs to better delineate the Starbucks access.
The City of Ottawa is developing a comprehensive Transportation Demand Management (TDM)
strategy as part of its efforts to reduce automobile dependency. TDM measures can reduce
transportation infrastructure requirements by encouraging people to change their travel mode,
The proximity of the site to two major Transitway stations (Dominion and Westboro stations)
provides residents of the proposed development with excellent access to mass transit
opportunities. The current site plan provides numerous on-site pedestrian connections to existing
sidewalks and multi-use pathways on/near the site, and a large pedestrian plaza. Through the site
plan approval process, these and other on-site amenities will be refined to create inviting spaces
that foster the use of healthy and sustainable non-auto modes of transportation
Other initiatives such as subsidies for bus passes, bike racks, vrtucar spaces, bicycle rental racks
are being considered for the site and will be finalised during the site plan approval process.

• The signalized intersection of Richmond Road and Roosevelt Avenue operates with acceptable
v/c ratios during the AM and PM peak hours in the 2015 buildout year and the 2020 horizon.
Maximum traffic queues on Richmond Road are not expected to impact adjacent intersections.
• At the Richmond Road and Churchill Avenue intersection, the westbound through movement
on Richmond Road and the southbound through movement on Churchill Avenue are expected
to operate with a failing LOS during the 2015 and 2020 PM peak hour. Minor adjustments to
traffic signal timing could offer marginal improvement, but cannot provide an acceptable LOS
• The City of Ottawa is aware of the existing traffic congestion at the Richmond Road and
Churchill Avenue intersection and throughout the Richmond Road corridor. Opportunities to
add additional capacity are limited, and are not supported by the community at large. The City
has studied the issue and is implementing a number of demand management strategies within
the Westboro community to achieve a 40% Transit Modal Share (TMS).
• The unsignalized intersection of Churchill Avenue and Wilmont Avenue operates with

• The unsignalized intersection of Churchill Avenue and Scott Street operates with acceptable
